(44) 625.6th November, 1944.WAR CABINET.FAR EASTERN COMMITTEE.Note by the Secretary of the War Cabinet.THE Prime Minister has approved the reconstitution of the former far eastern Committee. The Chairman of the Committee will be the parliamentary under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, and its members will be repre-sentatives of the following Departments : Treasury. Admiralty.Foreign Office. War Office.India Office. Air Ministry.Burma Office. Board of Trade.Colonial Office. Office of the Minister of Defence.Dominions Office.Representatives of other Departments will be invited to attend for thediscussion of particular items which may concern them.2. The terms of reference of the Committee are set out in the Annex to this paper.3. The Secretary of the Committee will be Mr. E. A. Armstrong, WarCabinet Offices.(Signed) E. E. BRIDGES.Offices of the War Cabinet, S.W. 1, -6th November, 1944.ANNEX.Terms of Reference.General Task.To keep under review and to advise, in collaboration as necessary with othercommittees, upon the general political and economic policy of His Majesty'sGovernment in the United Kingdom as regards the Far East and Pacific, withspecial regard to the desirability of close co-operation with His Majesty'governments in the Dominions, the Government' of India and foreign Govern-ments having interests in the Far Eastern and Pacific areas.Special Tasks.1. Without prejudice to the tasks falling within the terms of reference ofthe Official Committee on Armistice Terms and Civil Administration, toco-ordinate action on matters in the Far Eastern and Pacific areas which affectforeign policy and are of concern to more than one Department of His Majesty's[28527] Government; and, in particular, to consider questions concerning Hong Kong,Burma, Malaya, Borneo and other British territories in these areas which affect"the relations of His Majesty's Government with foreign countries. .* 2. To consider the future of Siam and Indo-China.3. To study and advise on questions relating to the eventual peace settlement with Japan and Siam and to post-war reconstruction in the Far Eastern andPacific areas which may be referred to it by the Armistice and Post-war committee or by the Chiefs of Staff, or to which it considers that the attentionof the Armistice and Post-War Committee or the Chiefs of Staff should be drawn. )4. To prepare papers describing the attitude of His Majesty's government towards Far Eastern and Pacific questions for communication to the United StatesGovernment, subject, where necessary, to Cabinet approval and- to Dominionconcurrence, with a view to removing misapprehensions as to the intentions and objectives of His Majesty's Goverment, encouraging the exchange of plans and suggestions and thereby promoting the maximum collaboration with theUnited States both during the war and in the postrwar reconstruction of theFar Eastern and Pacific areas.)
